title: Losing faith on campaign finance
content:
With a 2012 election flush with cash , reformers have largely lost faith in the president . | REUTERS Losing faith on campaign finance
Barack Obama has long cast himself as a warrior against the influence of big money in politics .
But as the 2012 election is saturated by billions of dollars , campaign-finance reformers have largely lost faith in a president they say is willfully neglecting his reformist agenda while cynically embracing key elements of a new , laissez-faire election system he ’ s long demonized .
The president , after all , granted his blessing earlier this year to Priorities USA Action , a super PAC run by two of his former staffers , to raise and spend unlimited sums of money from corporations , unions or individuals .
He stands to become the first chief executive not to successfully appoint someone to the Federal Election Commission .
The White House floated , then declined to issue an executive order restricting federal contractors that receive taxpayer dollars from “ interfering ” in elections .
It ditched a full-time “ ethics czar ” position when Obama nominated its occupant , Norm Eisen , ambassador to the Czech Republic .
The administration hasn ’ t responded to a plea to overhaul the FEC submitted in February by good-government types .
Nor has Obama pressed the Internal Revenue Service to go after nonprofits like the Karl Rove-inspired Crossroads GPS operation , which with its sister super PAC , American Crossroads , already has raised more than $ 100 million for this year ’ s election .
And he ’ s made no proposal to replace the nation ’ s presidential public funding system — a system he effectively cast into obsolescence four years ago by reneging on a promise to accept public campaign funds and then raising about $ 750 million — more than any other presidential candidate in U.S. history .
“ We ’ re seeing daily things get worse , ” said Public Citizen President Robert Weissman . “ And his failure of action will result in things growing even more worse . ”
David Bossie , president of the conservative Citizens United organization that prompted the eponymous Supreme Court case , couldn ’ t be happier .
“ Obama hasn ’ t been addressing these issues in any way , shape or form . It ’ s great for us , ” Bossie said . “ When it comes to campaign-finance issues , Obama certainly is better than George Bush . ”
Added Jim Bopp , the legal architect of the 2010 Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission : “ Obama has worked , it would seem , to abide by Citizens United , not try to undermine it . ”
In the days after the decision , Obama admonished the Supreme Court in his State of the Union address and used national speeches and weekly video addresses to rail against “ a potential corporate takeover of our elections ” that puts the “ integrity of our democracy ” at stake .
Elections , he said , should not “ be bankrolled by America ’ s most powerful interests , or worse , by foreign entities . ”
On the campaign trail , however , few such words pass Obama ’ s lips . No bold reform proposals headline a reelection agenda dominated by the economy , education and job creation .
Both the Obama campaign and White House defend the president , noting he signed an executive order on his first day in office strictly limiting lobbyists ’ access to the administration . Obama ’ s White House has done “ more than any administration in history ” to “ reduce the impact of special interests in Washington , ” White House spokesman Eric Schultz said .
Meanwhile , Obama doesn ’ t collect money from special-interest PACs or lobbyists , and about 98 percent of his donations come from people contributing $ 250 or less and the campaign voluntarily releases information on its top fundraising bundlers , campaign spokeswoman Katie Hogan said .
content_original:
With a 2012 election flush with cash, reformers have largely lost faith in the president. | REUTERS Losing faith on campaign finance

Barack Obama has long cast himself as a warrior against the influence of big money in politics.

But as the 2012 election is saturated by billions of dollars, campaign-finance reformers have largely lost faith in a president they say is willfully neglecting his reformist agenda while cynically embracing key elements of a new, laissez-faire election system he’s long demonized.

Story Continued Below

Perhaps that should be expected.

The president, after all, granted his blessing earlier this year to Priorities USA Action, a super PAC run by two of his former staffers, to raise and spend unlimited sums of money from corporations, unions or individuals.

He stands to become the first chief executive not to successfully appoint someone to the Federal Election Commission.

The White House floated, then declined to issue an executive order restricting federal contractors that receive taxpayer dollars from “interfering” in elections.

It ditched a full-time “ethics czar” position when Obama nominated its occupant, Norm Eisen, ambassador to the Czech Republic.

The administration hasn’t responded to a plea to overhaul the FEC submitted in February by good-government types.

Nor has Obama pressed the Internal Revenue Service to go after nonprofits like the Karl Rove-inspired Crossroads GPS operation, which with its sister super PAC, American Crossroads, already has raised more than $100 million for this year’s election.

And he’s made no proposal to replace the nation’s presidential public funding system — a system he effectively cast into obsolescence four years ago by reneging on a promise to accept public campaign funds and then raising about $750 million — more than any other presidential candidate in U.S. history.

“We’re seeing daily things get worse,” said Public Citizen President Robert Weissman. “And his failure of action will result in things growing even more worse.”

David Bossie, president of the conservative Citizens United organization that prompted the eponymous Supreme Court case, couldn’t be happier.

“Obama hasn’t been addressing these issues in any way, shape or form. It’s great for us,” Bossie said. “When it comes to campaign-finance issues, Obama certainly is better than George Bush.”

Added Jim Bopp, the legal architect of the 2010 Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission: “Obama has worked, it would seem, to abide by Citizens United, not try to undermine it.”

In the days after the decision, Obama admonished the Supreme Court in his State of the Union address and used national speeches and weekly video addresses to rail against “a potential corporate takeover of our elections” that puts the “integrity of our democracy” at stake.

Elections, he said, should not “be bankrolled by America’s most powerful interests, or worse, by foreign entities.”

On the campaign trail, however, few such words pass Obama’s lips. No bold reform proposals headline a reelection agenda dominated by the economy, education and job creation.

Both the Obama campaign and White House defend the president, noting he signed an executive order on his first day in office strictly limiting lobbyists’ access to the administration. Obama’s White House has done “more than any administration in history” to “reduce the impact of special interests in Washington,” White House spokesman Eric Schultz said.

Meanwhile, Obama doesn’t collect money from special-interest PACs or lobbyists, and about 98 percent of his donations come from people contributing $250 or less and the campaign voluntarily releases information on its top fundraising bundlers, campaign spokeswoman Katie Hogan said.
